channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: China Regroups to Snuff Out a Wave of Covid Protests
item.description: Communist Party officials are using decades-old tactics, along with some new ones, to quash the most widespread protests in decades. But Xi Jinping is silent.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley
item.media:credit: Kevin Frayer/Getty Images
item.media:description: Protesters holding up a white piece of paper against censorship as they march during a protest against Chinas strict zero COVID measures in Beijing, China, on Sunday.

item.title: China Protests Over ‘Zero Covid’ Follow Months of Economic Pain
item.description: President Xi Jinping’s unbending approach to the pandemic has hurt businesses and strangled growth, squeezing the world’s second-largest economy.
item.dc:creator: Daisuke Wakabayashi, Olivia Wang and Joy Dong
item.media:credit: The New York Times
item.media:description: Police presence was heavy on Sunday in an area of Shanghai where protesters had gathered the night before.

item.title: NATO Meets to Discuss Defense Aid to Sustain Ukraine Through Winter
item.description: The U.S. is planning an emergency cash injection for Ukraine to shore up its energy infrastructure after an onslaught of Russian attacks.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Tyler Hicks/The New York Times
item.media:description: A resident on Monday in Sviatohirsk, a small town in eastern Ukraine that was retaken from Russian forces.

item.title: Russian Retreat Reveals Signs of an Atrocity in a Ukrainian Village
item.description: In the southern Kherson region, the pattern seen in eastern Ukraine is repeating: The withdrawal of Russian forces yields evidence of possible war crimes.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman and Finbarr O’Reilly
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Workers exhuming bodies from a communal grave in the southern Ukrainian village of Pravdyne.

item.title: Proud, Scared and Conflicted. What the China Protesters Told Me.
item.description: In more than a dozen interviews, young people explained how the events of the past few days became what one called a “tipping point.”
item.dc:creator: Li Yuan
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: The New York Times
item.media:description: A protest in Shanghai on Sunday drew crowds and a heavy police presence.

item.title: Why Protesters in China Are Using Blank Sheets of White Paper
item.description: In a country where the authorities have little tolerance for open dissent, demonstrators against Covid restrictions have turned to more subtle methods.
item.dc:creator: Chang Che and Amy Chang Chien
item.media:credit: Hector Retamal/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A paper placed on a wall during a protest in Shanghai on Sunday read “I didn’t say anything.”

item.title: The Covid Protests in China, Explained
item.description: After a weekend of confrontations between officials and demonstrators, video from two sites in Shanghai and Beijing showed a heavy security presence. Here’s the latest on the situation.
item.dc:creator: Vivek Shankar
item.media:credit: Ng Han Guan/Associated Press

item.title: Isabel dos Santos, Daughter of Angola’s Ex-President, Faces Arrest on Corruption Charges
item.description: Isabel dos Santos, the daughter of Angola’s former president, was accused of enriching herself with state resources during her time in control of the country’s oil company.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon
item.media:credit: Toby Melville/Reuters
item.media:description: Isabel dos Santos, the daughter of Angola’s longtime president José Eduardo dos Santos. Mr. dos Santos stepped down in 2017 and died in July.

item.title: A Sikh Temple in India Fights Loneliness With Companionship
item.description: A village in northern India has found a way to address a growing global issue: a deep sense of isolation among older people.
item.dc:creator: Karan Deep Singh
item.media:credit: Atul Loke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Karnail Singh Kakkar, in orange, with his friends at a village temple in Kakkar, northern India. The village began its experiment in dealing with the loneliness of older residents almost a decade ago.

item.title: Navalny Team Uses YouTube From Exile to Lift Anti-War Effort
item.description: The political network of Aleksei A. Navalny, the imprisoned opposition leader, had seemingly been crushed. But working from abroad, the Navalny team is using YouTube to spearhead antiwar efforts.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar
item.media:credit: Andrej Vasilenko for The New York Times
item.media:description: Irina Alleman, left, interviewing a Russian journalist, Tikhon Dzyadko, in Vilnius, Lithuania, on Popular Politics, a new YouTube channel run by the Russian opposition movement founded by Aleksei Navalny.

item.title: A U.S.-Iran Soccer Showdown Intensifies With Protests as a Backdrop
item.description: The unrest that has gripped Iran for the past two months has heightened what would already have been a tense encounter at the World Cup in Qatar on Tuesday between the two geopolitical foes.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.media:credit: Frank Augstein/Associated Press
item.media:description: Iran’s players during the singing of the national anthem ahead of their match with Wales at the World Cup in Al Rayyan, Qatar, on Friday.

item.title: Amid Scandals and Politics, Poland’s Youths Lose Faith in Catholic Church
item.description: The Polish church is in a deep crisis, as its authority is sapped by cascading sexual abuse scandals and as more people grow wary of its perceived alliance with the country’s right-wing government.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Maciek Nabrdalik for The New York Times
item.media:description: Parishioners in Piaski, Poland, celebrating the visit of a copy of a revered Polish icon, the Black Madonna of Czestochowa, in September.

item.title: ​How Britain Turned ‘Modern Slavery’ Law Against Low-Level Drug Dealers
item.description: A law written to prevent human trafficking is being wielded against low-level drug dealers. The effects are long-lasting.
item.dc:creator: Selam Gebrekidan
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Glodi Wabelua was serving a prison sentence for drug dealing when he was charged and tried under Britain’s Modern Slavery Act.

item.title: For Visits With Michelangelo’s David, She Brings a Duster
item.description: The revered statue in Italy is not going to dust itself. That’s where Eleonora Pucci comes in.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:credit: Chiara Negrello for The New York Times
item.media:description: Eleonora Pucci at work last week in the Galleria dell’Accademia in Florence, Italy.

item.title: Trump’s Far-right Embrace
item.description: Why it’s important to know more about Nick Fuentes.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.media:credit: Nicole Hester/Ann Arbor News, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Nick Fuentes during a rally at the Michigan State Capitol in Lansing in 2020

item.title: One Step Closer to a Universal Flu Vaccine?
item.description: Scientists have tested in animals a vaccine that may protect against 20 strains of influenza, helping to prevent another pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.media:credit: Mark J. Terrill/Associated Press
item.media:description: Current influenza vaccines protect against seasonal flu but would provide little protection against a new strain that may emerge as a pandemic threat.

item.title: As Haiti Unravels, U.S. Officials Push to Send in an Armed Foreign Force
item.description: Fearing a mass exodus, some Biden officials are pressing for a multinational force, but they don’t want to send U.S. troops and haven’t been able to persuade other countries to take the lead.
item.dc:creator: Natalie Kitroeff and Adriana Zehbrauskas
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:credit: Adriana Zehbrauskas for The New York Times
item.media:description: An officer from Haiti’s National Police SWAT team in an armored vehicle while patrolling Cite Soleil, a neighborhood controlled by gangs in the capital city of Port-au-Prince.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Ukrainian military officials say Russia is planning more strikes on infrastructure.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Bernat Armangue/Associated Press
item.media:description: Older residents are evacuated from Kherson, Ukraine, on Sunday.

item.title: China to Launch Astronauts to Tiangong Space Station: How to Watch
item.description: The crew will set off from a secretive desert launch center to rendezvous with fellow astronauts aboard Tiangong, the country’s newly completed outpost in orbit.
item.dc:creator: Keith Bradsher
item.media:credit: via Reuters
item.media:description: A Long March-2F rocket, carrying the Shenzhou 15 spacecraft, at Jiuquan Satellite Launch Center in China last week.

item.title: Ukraine Warns of More Strikes on Power Plants, as Russians Dig In
item.description: Russian forces are fortifying positions in southern Ukraine after retreating from Kherson, and the Kremlin denied planning to withdraw from the Zaporizhzhia nuclear plant.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg, Marc Santora and Maria Varenikova
item.media:credit: Bernat Armangue/Associated Press
item.media:description: Older residents are evacuated from Kherson on Sunday.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing: Anxiety in China
item.description: Plus Ukraine updates, a U.S.-Iran World Cup preview and a “She Said” interview.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: She Said: Breaking the Sexual Harassment Story That Helped Ignite a Movement (Book)
item.media:credit: Kevin Frayer/Getty Images
item.media:description: People held up a white piece of paper against censorship during a protest in Beijing on Sunday.

item.title: Chinese Unrest Over Lockdown Upends Global Economic Outlook
item.description: Growing protests in the world’s biggest manufacturing nation add a new element of uncertainty atop the Ukraine war, an energy crisis and inflation.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Cohen
item.media:credit: Kevin Frayer/Getty Images
item.media:description: Demonstrators in Beijing held blank pieces of paper to protest censorship as unrest in China over Covid-19 lockdowns grew on Sunday.

item.title: Russia Postpones Nuclear Arms Meeting, US Officials Say
item.description: The treaty, New START, calls for reciprocal inspections, but they have not been occurring, first because of the coronavirus pandemic, and now amid tensions over U.S. sanctions on Russia.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.media:credit: Maxim Shipenkov/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: A monument to Russia’s nuclear weapons history in Moscow. The country postponed a meeting with officials from the United States to discuss the last remaining nuclear treaty between the two nations.

item.title: Mpox: WHO Renames Monkeypox Citing Racial Stigma
item.description: Health experts said the old nomenclature was imprecise, played into racist stereotypes and fueled stigmatization, making it harder to contain the most recent outbreaks.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Jacobs
item.media:credit: N.I.H./Universal Images Group, via Getty Images
item.media:description: An electron micrograph of monkeypox particles, in pink, within an infected cell, in green.

item.title: At a China Covid Protest, a Mix of Giddy Elation and Anxiety
item.description: In a country where protests are swiftly quashed, many who gathered to voice their discontent — under the watchful eye of the police — were uncertain about how far to go.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang
item.media:credit: Thomas Peter/Reuters

item.title: Russian Forces Fortify Lines of Defense in Southern Ukraine
item.description: The Institute for the Study of War said Russia appears to view the prospect of a Ukrainian counteroffensive as a serious threat after Moscow pulled back from Kherson.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Antonivsky Bridge, which was destroyed by retreating Russian forces, earlier this month in the southern Ukrainian city of Kherson.

item.title: Belarus’s Foreign Minister Dies Suddenly, State Media Reports
item.description: Vladimir Makei served 10 years as the foreign minister of Belarus, a key geopolitical battleground between Russia and the West.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev and Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Associated Press
item.media:description: Vladimir Makei in Kyiv, Belarus, in February.

item.title: Pandemic Learning Loss
item.description: The role remote education played.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Mervosh
item.media:credit: Jim Wilson/The New York Times
item.media:description: Pre Calculus Class at George Washington High School in San Francisco in 2021.

item.title: 3 Weeks After Hack, This Country’s Government Is Still Off-line
item.description: The Pacific Island nation of Vanuatu has said little about a Nov. 6 cyberattack that has significantly inconvenienced many of its 320,000 people.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:credit: Mario Tama/Getty Images
item.media:description: A local news outlet called the cyberattack in Vanuatu “our worst kept secret.”

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: Anger over Covid restrictions in China has created a crisis for its leader, Xi Jinping.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Hector Retamal/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Police officers on Sunday blocked Urumqi Road, where protests had taken place the night before.

item.title: Mexico’s President Leads Supporters in March Through Capital
item.description: Tens of thousands of Mexicans walked through the streets Sunday to show their support for President Andrés Manuel López Obrador amid some pushback to his political agenda in recent weeks.
item.dc:creator: Steve Fisher and Maria Abi-Habib
item.media:credit: Luis Antonio Rojas for The New York Times
item.media:description: Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador, Mexico’s president, during a rally in support of the proposed electoral reform in Mexico City, Mexico on Sunday.

item.title: Siege Ends After Shabab Gunmen Storm Somalia Hotel
item.description: An extremist group, Al Shabab, claimed responsibility for the 22-hour gun-and-bomb assault in the Somali capital, which ended with the death of all six attackers.
item.dc:creator: Hussein Mohamed and Declan Walsh
item.media:credit: Guy Peterson/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Central Mogadishu this month. As the Somali government has stepped up military operations against Al Shabab, the militants have escalated their bombing campaign in the capital.

item.title: Landslide Kills at Least 14 at Funeral in Cameroon
item.description: Rescuers were still searching for people who might have been swept up in the disaster.
item.dc:creator: Reuters
item.media:credit: Amindeh Blaise Atabong/Reuters
item.media:description: Rescue crews and officials with the bodies of victims after a landslide in Cameroon’s capital on Sunday.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing: Covid Protests Intensify in China
item.description: Plus World Cup updates, Kiribati’s judicial shake-up and “Gangnam Style,” 10 years later.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Qilai Shen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Heavy police presence and crowds of residents near the Wulumuqi Road area in Shanghai, where a second evening of protest against China’s strict Covid-19 policy were anticipated to take police, on Sunday.

item.title: Ukraine’s Progress Threatened by the Challenges of Winter Weather
item.description: Officials urged Ukrainians to continue conserving energy, as analysts said that deteriorating weather was one factor slowing Ukraine’s battlefield progress.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Members of Ukraine’s Territorial Defense Force took part in a tactical training exercise south of Kyiv on Friday.

item.title: Roman Coins Thought for Centuries to Be Fakes Get a Fresh Appraisal
item.description: New research suggests that the gold coins, which were found in 1713 and long dismissed as forgeries, may be authentic.
item.dc:creator: April Rubin
item.media:credit: The Hunterian - University of Glasgow, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Long considered fake, gold coins like this one bearing the image of a mysterious third-century figure named Sponsian may be authentic, researchers say.

item.title: In Ukraine, Bakhmut Becomes a Bloody Vortex for 2 Militaries
item.description: Even as they have celebrated successes elsewhere, Ukrainian forces in one small eastern city have endured relentless Russian attacks. And the struggle to hold it is only intensifying.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Natalia Yermak and Tyler Hicks
item.media:credit: Tyler Hicks/The New York Times

item.title: Deadly Fire in China Fuels Protests Over Xi’s Covid Policies
item.description: Protests became rare once the government cut off most routes to collective action. But ubiquitous Covid rules, bringing shared suffering, have created a focus for anger.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley, Vivian Wang, Chang Che and Amy Chang Chien
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Ng Han Guan/Associated Press

item.title: Cholera and Crime
item.description: Haiti is in the midst of a humanitarian disaster.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:credit: Adriana Zehbrauskas for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jameson Batz, 4, cries next to his mother, Fanis Pierre, 30, in Port-au-Prince, Haiti.

item.title: Beauty Over Brains: Japan’s Skin-Deep University Pageants
item.description: The contests reflect a culture that often judges women by their appearance and slots them into rigid, gender-defined roles.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich and Hikari Hida
item.media:credit: Shiho Fukada for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yuki Iozumi, center, and other finalists of the Miss Mister Aoyama pageants in Tokyo last month. Critics argue that the competitions promote stereotypical beauty standards.

item.title: French Police Guard Water as Seasonal Drought Intensifies
item.description: New reservoirs designed to supply French farms with water in increasingly arid growing seasons have attracted opposition from environmentalists.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter
item.media:credit: Andrea Mantovani for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Mauzé-sur-le-Mignon reservoir is the first of 16 planned in the Deux-Sèvres region.

item.title: Amid Israeli Blockade on Gaza, a Fishing Fleet Limps Along
item.description: An Israeli blockade that restricts the movement of Gazans out of the strip and limits imports — or bans them completely — has been devastating for the enclave’s fishing industry.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim
item.media:credit: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Palestinian fisherman carrying his bounty after a trip out to the sea along the Gaza Strip.

item.title: Protests Erupt in Shanghai and Other Chinese Cities Over Covid Controls
item.description: A chanting crowd called for China’s leader, Xi Jinping, to step down, a rare act of defiance reflecting growing anger after nearly three years of lockdowns.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley and Muyi Xiao
item.media:credit: via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Protesters shouting slogans as police officers looked on in Shanghai on Saturday.

item.title: U.S. Allows Chevron to Expand Energy Operations in Venezuela
item.description: The license, limited in scope, was issued amid the resumption of talks between the Venezuelan government and opposition, and comes as President Nicolás Maduro desperately needs to improve the economy.
item.dc:creator: Julie Turkewitz and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Cardon oil refinery in Punto Fijo, Venezuela. Years of U.S. sanctions on oil and gas have cut the country’s profits.

item.title: Meet the Man on a Mission to Expose Sneaky Price Increases
item.description: Edgar Dworsky has become the go-to expert on “shrinkflation,” when products or packaging are manipulated so people get less for their money.
item.dc:creator: Clare Toeniskoetter
item.media:credit: Simon Simard for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mr. Dworsky said he looks out for clues like “new and improved” on packaging.

item.title: This Country’s Top Judges Were All Foreigners. Now They’re Gone.
item.description: The president’s suspension of five jurists in the Pacific nation of Kiribati highlights the outsize role noncitizen judges play in the region.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Taneti Maamau of Kiribati accused foreign judges of trying to undermine the Pacific island nation’s sovereignty.

item.title: Landslide on Italian Island Sweeps Away Homes and Turns Roads Into Rivers of Mud
item.description: At least one person was killed and an estimated 10 others were missing on the island of Ischia, a popular tourist destination off the coast of Naples.
item.dc:creator: Gaia Pianigiani
item.media:credit: Ciro De Luca/Reuters
item.media:description: Vehicles were dragged into the sea on Saturday when a landslide hit the southern Italian island of Ischia.

item.title: Ukraine Draws Parallels Between Holodomor and Russia’s Strikes
item.description: The Holodomor commemoration came as President Vladimir V. Putin was accused of degrading Ukraine’s power grid to freeze the country into submission.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Cassandra Vinograd
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Placing candles on Saturday at a memorial to honor the victims of the Holodomor, a famine engineered in 1932 by Joseph Stalin that killed millions of Ukrainians.

item.title: Holiday Rituals
item.description: The season is a time of customs, of traditions repeated year after year.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: Tech Turmoil Complicates Canada’s Policing of the Online World
item.description: The government has four bills before Parliament to rein in tech giants at a time when the industry is retrenching.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.media:description: Google, which has a large office in Kitchener, Ontario, is among the tech giants with Canadian operations.

item.title: They Were Surrogates. Now They Must Raise the Children.
item.description: In Cambodia’s weak legal system, surrogacy exists in a gray market, endangering all involved when political conditions suddenly shift and criminal charges follow.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Beech and Nadia Shira Cohen
item.media:credit: Nadia Shira Cohen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hun Daneth chose to be a surrogate for a Chinese businessman. After Cambodia banned the practice, she was forced by the courts to raise the child or risk going to jail.

item.title: A Timely Biography Traces Joseph Roth’s Accounts of Fascism
item.description: Roth was an outraged witness to tyranny, which led him to exile, and his books to the bonfire. In “Endless Flight,” Keiron Pim examines the flawed man and his resonant legacy.
item.dc:creator: Casey Schwartz
item.category: Endless Flight: The Life of Joseph Roth (Book)
item.media:credit: Leo Baeck Institute, via Bridgeman Images
item.media:description: Joseph Roth left Vienna for Paris in the 1920s amid mounting tensions. His 1923 book, “The Spider’s Web,” mentioned Adolf Hitler by name, though Hitler was then still a decade from gaining power.

item.title: Happy Birthday, Omicron
item.description: One year after the variant’s discovery, virologists are still scrambling to keep up with Omicron’s rapid evolution.
item.dc:creator: Carl Zimmer

item.title: U.S. and NATO Scramble to Arm Ukraine and Refill Their Own Arsenals
item.description: The West thought an artillery and tank war in Europe would never happen again and shrank weapons stockpiles. It was wrong.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger and Lara Jakes
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian forces preparing to fire an M-777 howitzer at Russian positions in the Donetsk region in May.

item.title: As Venezuelan Antagonists Talk, the U.S. Softens Its Stance
item.description: Negotiations between the Venezuelan government and opposition could lead to an easing of the country’s protracted crisis.
item.dc:creator: Julie Turkewitz
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: A rally for a mayoral candidate in Caracas last November. European election observers later said the vote was neither free nor fair.

item.title: Kherson Evacuates Hospitals Under Relentless Russian Shelling
item.description: “This is the revenge of those who lost,” the Ukrainian president, Volodymyr Zelensky, said of Russia’s attacks.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:credit: Bernat Armangue/Associated Press
item.media:description: City workers collecting the body of a woman in Kherson, in southern Ukraine, on Friday.

item.title: Under a Cross Atop a Shallow Grave, He Found His Father
item.description: The full extent of Russian war crimes in the city of Kherson and surrounding areas is just coming into focus. These were two of them.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Addario and Marc Santora
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Serhiy Novosad, 26, carrying the body of his father in his yard in Lvivsky Otrubi, a village in the Kherson region of Ukraine, on Wednesday.

item.title: Catholic Church Issues Guidelines for Ethical Investing
item.description: In the midst of a criminal trial of 10 church officials on charges of financial impropriety, the church put forth a long-delayed document that lays out standards for avoiding improper investments.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:credit: Tiziana Fabi/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: St. Peter’s Basilica at the Vatican last week. The church says it has cleaned up its financial act after a long history of accusations of murky dealings.

item.title: Putin Holds Highly Choreographed Meeting With Mothers of Russian Soldiers
item.description: The televised event came amid intensifying public criticism over the conditions recent Russian conscripts have been forced to bear.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Alexander Shcherbak/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: President Vladimir Putin of Russia meeting with mothers of Russian soldiers outside Moscow on Friday.

item.title: Merkel Says She Lacked the Power to Dissuade Putin from Invading Ukraine
item.description: Recounting her last state visit to Moscow in August of 2021, Angela Merkel noted that President Vladimir V. Putin would not meet with her alone, as he had done in the past.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:credit: Andre Kosters/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Former German chancellor Angela Merkel in Lisbon in October.
